page.title: 15EASTHAM, 60 YEARS OF CHANGE
page.content: COAL,GOODS AND PASSENGERS, CAME IN BY THE RAILWAY AT NEWNHAM BRIDGE.FRUIT IN SEASON LEFT BY AFTERNOON TRAIN FOR CITY MORNING MARKETS_ ALL 7 DAYS OF THE WEEK.WEEKDAY BUSES TO AND FROM WORCESTER RAN 3 TIMES DAILY WITH EXTRA ONES TO TENBURY AND KIDDERMINSTER ON MARKET DAYS.BUSES CARRIED GOODS, POULTRY AND EGGS ETC. AS WELL AS PASSENGERS. EASTHAM HAD ITS OWN HALL,SCHOOL,POST OFFICE,SHOP AND SMITHY. CATTLE AND SHEEP WERE DRIVEN ON FOOT BY THEIR OWNERS TO TENBURY MARKET.MOST FARMERS AND MANY COTTAGERS KEPT A PIG FOR SLAUGHTER. NEARLY ALL FARMERS MADE THEIR OWN CIDER AND EVEN SMALLHOLDINGS COULD GROW HOPS. CORN HARVEST WAS A TIME TO CATCH RABBITS AS REAPERS CLOSED IN, AND THRESHING REDUCED RATS AS NEIGHBOURS WITH TERRIERS CAME FOR THE SPORT.
